**G.L. c. 218, \u00a719**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19**, and **G.L. c. 231, §1**, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Brockton, Plymouth County.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a71**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19**, and **G.L. c. 231, §1**, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Brockton, Plymouth County.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a78**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, §8**, because the property at issue is located in this judicial district and the Defendant conducts business here.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a714**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and violation of this right entitles the tenant to **actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater**, plus court costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.

- *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (.raw_text: - *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord liable where interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment results from activities under landlord’s control).
- *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
- *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff concerns noise from a bar operated on nearby premises leased by the landlord and the landlord’s resulting liability for constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment based on conditions the landlord could control. It does not address failures to provide or restore essential services such as heat or hot water. While it cites other cases (e.g., Burt, Shindler) that involve heat, light, and similar services as examples of breaches of quiet enjoyment, Blackett itself is not authority for the specific proposition about essential services; it uses those earlier cases illustratively.
- *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942)… Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33-34 (1933) (failure to install necessary heating system, as agreed).”

- *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.raw_text: - *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (relief appropriate where landlord’s conduct substantially impaired habitability).
- *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
- *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The proposition is about failure to provide essential services such as heat or hot water constituting a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Simon v. Solomon involves repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions, not denial of heat, hot water, or similar utilities. While the case does construe G.L. c. 186, § 14 and affirms that serious interferences with habitability (here, flooding) can violate quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically address failure to provide or restore essential services like heat or hot water, so it does not squarely support the precise proposition stated.
- *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14…imposes civil and criminal liability on a landlord that ‘willfully or intentionally’ fails to provide essential services that it is obligated to furnish, or ‘directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.’… The jury found in answer to a special question…that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

- *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1.raw_text: - *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (prolonged loss of utilities and amenities violates G.L. c. 186, §14).
- *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
- *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1.support_reasoning: The case does not deal with utilities, heat, hot water, or other essential services. It addresses whether a statutory lead-paint violation, by itself, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. While the opinion cites prior quiet enjoyment cases (some of which involve failure to repair defects), it does not itself establish that failure to provide heat or hot water violates the covenant, so it does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
- *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

- *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 37.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
- *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 37.support_reasoning: The opinion is about breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement due to lack of heat and hot water; it does not analyze or even mention the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court frames the loss of essential services solely as a material breach of the warranty of habitability, not as a violation of quiet enjoyment, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
- *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 37.relevant_excerpt: "He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability.... We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability."

App..support_reasoning: The provided opinion is about the commitment and discharge of a sexually dangerous person under G.L. c. 123A and related equal protection and procedural issues. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, essential services, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss heat, hot water, or repair obligations. Therefore it cannot support the proposition that failure to provide or restore essential services constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
- *Petrocelli v. Shuman*, 35 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: Throughout his life and particularly while at Bridgewater, Redgate has exhibited alarming social pathology. His language is foul and his temper is explosive. He is engaged in constant conflict with treatment center personnel, verbally abusing them, threatening to kill them, calling them degrading names, and demeaning them. ... His prison and treatment record, however, is devoid of entries of sexual misconduct and his quite considerable criminal record is similarly free of sexual offenses, except for the one of which he was convicted.

- *McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 3.raw_text: - *McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977) (landlord’s acts or omissions causing interference violate §14).
- *McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 3.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
- *McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 3.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability based on State Sanitary Code violations and does not involve G.L. c. 186, § 14 or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court discusses how to measure rent abatement and what defects are material but never addresses failure to provide or restore essential services like heat or hot water as constituting a violation of quiet enjoyment. The parenthetical in the citation (landlord’s acts or omissions causing interference violate §14) is not reflected in this excerpt, and nothing here supports the specific proposition stated.
- *McKenna v. Begin*, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 3.relevant_excerpt: “One other point warrants mention. McKenna argues that code violations in common areas of the building such as the hallways and the basement should have been considered in awarding damages. We agree in principle that violations in common areas which detract from a tenant’s use or enjoyment of the portion of the premises leased to him can result in damages against the landlord. See Javins, 428 F. 2d, at 1082, n.62. … On remand the judge is to make a finding on this point and if the violations did exist from the outset, he is to determine whether they caused a diminution in the value of McKenna’s use and enjoyment of the premises and compute damages on the basis of that determination.”

- *Lowell Hous. Auth. v. Melendez*, 449.raw_text: - *Lowell Hous. Auth. v. Melendez*, 449 Mass. 34 (2007) (emphasizing remedial purpose of tenant-protection statutes).
- *Lowell Hous. Auth. v. Melendez*, 449.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
- *Lowell Hous. Auth. v. Melendez*, 449.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns eviction from public housing based on off-premises violent criminal activity and the statutory/lease language about protecting other tenants’ ‘health, safety, or right to peaceful enjoyment.’ It does not discuss essential services, heat, hot water, habitability, or the common-law/statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment in the landlord-tenant context. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition that failure to provide or restore essential services constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
- *Lowell Hous. Auth. v. Melendez*, 449.relevant_excerpt: “The lease provision in this case is in accordance with language contained in both the Federal and the State public housing statutes. Nothing in the lease, or in either statute, restricts the provision of ‘any criminal activity’ to activity that occurs on the premises. Not all criminal activity, however, is cause for termination. The limiting factor is that the criminal activity must ‘threaten[] the health, safety, or right to peaceful enjoyment’ of other tenants. … The ‘one strike’ policy seeks not to punish, but rather to ensure the safety and quiet enjoyment of other tenants.”

- *Townsend v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 436.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:

Auth.*, 436.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a criminal homicide/DNA/Miranda decision and does not concern landlord-tenant law, essential services, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. There is no discussion of G.L. c. 186, §14, quiet enjoyment, or conditions such as heat or hot water. Therefore, this case, at least as excerpted, does not support the cited proposition about failures to provide essential services violating the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
- *Townsend v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 436.relevant_excerpt:
We have examined the record pursuant to our obligation under G. L. c. 278, § 33E. There is no basis to grant the defendant relief.

Judgment affirmed.

- *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: - *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (lack of heat and hot water is substantial interference).
- *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that failure to provide or restore essential services, such as heat or hot water, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
- *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s regulatory obligation to supply heat and hot water and holds that this obligation cannot be shifted to the tenant absent a written agreement under the State Sanitary Code. It does not analyze or decide whether failure to provide or restore heat or hot water constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about quiet enjoyment, even though it addresses related utility obligations.
- *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’… The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”
